content: Palin has done a pretty good job as Governor in Alaska. She had (and may still have) over an 80% approval rating before the election. She may have ended up as a decent candidate on the national stage in the future but she was not ready in 2008 and she will never recover from the beating she's taken (and continues to take). Most of it is her and John McCain's fault, but it is also true that there was a fair amount of simple bias.
reply: Palin has done a pretty good job as Governor in Alaska. She had (and may still have) over an 80% approval rating before the election. She may have ended up as a decent candidate on the national stage in the future but she was not ready in 2008 and she will never recover from the beating she's taken (and continues to take). content: quote: Originally posted by foxred03: Palin has done a pretty good job as Governor in Alaska. She had (and may still have) over an 80% approval rating before the election. She may have ended up as a decent candidate on the national stage in the future but she was not ready in 2008 and she will never recover from the beating she's taken (and continues to take). Most of it is her and John McCain's fault, but it is also true that there was a fair amount of simple bias. A poll at conservatives4palin.com shows her with 60% approval about 35% very positive in March. This poll is from before Ms. Palin’s highly controversial choice of Wayne Anthony Ross as Attorney General, her not attending the meeting with Alaskan Legislators to discuss the stimulus money, and before her press release on that matter which Republican Senate President Gary Stevens called “absolutely false”, note attacks by Repubs might hurt her approval in Alaska.

content: Anyone would have to admit that Alaska has got to be the easiest state in the country to govern. People wise there are a less than most major american cities. I mean you have Achorage, Fairbanks and Juneau, beyond that what do you have a buch of little towns like Wasilla or others that are little more than eskimo villages that as long as they get there "permanent fund" checks every year could care less about the state goverment. From a actual run things standpoint all she or any of her previous govenors have ever really had to do is re-distribute money that either comes in from the oil companies or in the form of earmarks from the federal goverment. Tough buget choices? No it is more a case of figuring out what to spend it on, it has never really been a case of needing to choose between for example laying off teachers or other state workers or not doing some other state goverment thing that they (the other states) can not afford to do. My dad was mayor of a town bigger than Wasilla and a county supervisor. I am sure he could run Alaska just fine too but would be way out of his league trying to run my home state of WI.

title: Gingrich: Palin won't be future GOP leader

content: quote: Originally posted by IHAWKER: I don’t think it takes a genius to know that Gov. Palin will not be a driving force in the future GOP. More bad news for the GOP. There have been 38 presidential elections since 1860, and Obama received the 6th highest share of the vote for a Democrat. Only FDR (four times) and LBJ (once) exceeded Obama’s percentage. There were three giant demographic shifts that powered this: “— The young broke more than 2-1 Democratic, and it was an intense preference unlikely to fade quickly. As this group ages and replaces older voters, Democrats will benefit even more since this group’s turnout will go up. “— The proportion of minority voters (black, Hispanic, and Asian) shot up and is likely to climb consistently every four years (mainly because of Hispanics). Democrats get about three-quarters of the votes of minorities, taken as a collective group. “— Americans with post-graduate educations have begun to move firmly to the Democrats, not just because of Bush and the economy but also because of the GOP’s conservative stance on social issues (abortion, gay rights, etc.) “Republicans will be in the wilderness for a while, whatever they do. If they want to shorten that time, though, they need to focus on the three populations we discuss in the book. There are many ways to increase their attractiveness, but one essential ingredient is to deemphasize social issues — as unhappy as that may make some fundamentalist Christians.” From a new book out by The University of Virginia’s Larry J. Sabato “The Year of Obama: How Barack Obama Won the White House.” http://www.politico.com/playbook/0409/playbook653.html
quote: Originally posted by IHAWKER: I don’t think it takes a genius to know that Gov. Palin will not be a driving force in the future GOP.
reply: More bad news for the GOP. There have been 38 presidential elections since 1860, and Obama received the 6th highest share of the vote for a Democrat. Only FDR (four times) and LBJ (once) exceeded Obama’s percentage. There were three giant demographic shifts that powered this: “— The young broke more than 2-1 Democratic, and it was an intense preference unlikely to fade quickly. As this group ages and replaces older voters, Democrats will benefit even more since this group’s turnout will go up. “— The proportion of minority voters (black, Hispanic, and Asian) shot up and is likely to climb consistently every four years (mainly because of Hispanics). Democrats get about three-quarters of the votes of minorities, taken as a collective group. “— Americans with post-graduate educations have begun to move firmly to the Democrats, not just because of Bush and the economy but also because of the GOP’s conservative stance on social issues (abortion, gay rights, etc.) “Republicans will be in the wilderness for a while, whatever they do. If they want to shorten that time, though, they need to focus on the three populations we discuss in the book. There are many ways to increase their attractiveness, but one essential ingredient is to deemphasize social issues — as unhappy as that may make some fundamentalist Christians.” From a new book out by The University of Virginia’s Larry J. Sabato “The Year of Obama: How Barack Obama Won the White House.” http://www.politico.com/playbook/0409/playbook653.html

Whether they want to admit it or not, it's true. Also, it doesn't help that Mexicans have finally seen through the cloud that Republicans have long held over their heads (as indicated by all the Blue votes along the Rio Grande on the last election). Actually I don't think the country has shifted to being more liberal I think that the Republican party has shifted further to the right with many of the local party organizations being controlled by religious and/or social conservatives. This control by the party extreme is the same problem that the Demos had from the 70's until the 90's (for the Demos the extreme left lost "control" after losing several elections) and will force Repub candidates to present positions most of the country will think are to extreme to get nominated.

No it is more a case of figuring out what to spend it on, it has never really been a case of needing to choose between for example laying off teachers or other state workers or not doing some other state goverment thing that they (the other states) can not afford to do. My dad was mayor of a town bigger than Wasilla and a county supervisor. I am sure he could run Alaska just fine too but would be way out of his league trying to run my home state of WI.
reply: Anyone would have to admit that Alaska has got to be the easiest state in the country to govern. People wise there are a less than most major american cities. I mean you have Achorage, Fairbanks and Juneau, beyond that what do you have a buch of little towns like Wasilla or others that are little more than eskimo villages that as long as they get there "permanent fund" checks every year could care less about the state goverment. From a actual run things standpoint all she or any of her previous govenors have ever really had to do is re-distribute money that either comes in from the oil companies or in the form of earmarks from the federal goverment. Tough buget choices? No it is more a case of figuring out what to spend it on, it has never really been a case of needing to choose between for example laying off teachers or other state workers or not doing some other state goverment thing that they (the other states) can not afford to do. My dad was mayor of a town bigger than Wasilla and a county supervisor. I am sure he could run Alaska just fine too but would be way out of his league trying to run my home state of WI.
title: Gingrich: Palin won't be future GOP leader

content: I don’t think it takes a genius to know that Gov. Palin will not be a driving force in the future GOP.
reply: I don’t think it takes a genius to know that Gov. Palin will not be a driving force in the future GOP.
title: Gingrich: Palin won't be future GOP leader

content: quote: Originally posted by IHAWKER: I don’t think it takes a genius to know that Gov. Palin will not be a driving force in the future GOP. More bad news for the GOP. There have been 38 presidential elections since 1860, and Obama received the 6th highest share of the vote for a Democrat. Only FDR (four times) and LBJ (once) exceeded Obama’s percentage. There were three giant demographic shifts that powered this: “— The young broke more than 2-1 Democratic, and it was an intense preference unlikely to fade quickly. As this group ages and replaces older voters, Democrats will benefit even more since this group’s turnout will go up. “— The proportion of minority voters (black, Hispanic, and Asian) shot up and is likely to climb consistently every four years (mainly because of Hispanics). Democrats get about three-quarters of the votes of minorities, taken as a collective group. “— Americans with post-graduate educations have begun to move firmly to the Democrats, not just because of Bush and the economy but also because of the GOP’s conservative stance on social issues (abortion, gay rights, etc.) “Republicans will be in the wilderness for a while, whatever they do. If they want to shorten that time, though, they need to focus on the three populations we discuss in the book. There are many ways to increase their attractiveness, but one essential ingredient is to deemphasize social issues — as unhappy as that may make some fundamentalist Christians.” From a new book out by The University of Virginia’s Larry J. Sabato “The Year of Obama: How Barack Obama Won the White House.” http://www.politico.com/playbook/0409/playbook653.html
quote: Originally posted by IHAWKER: I don’t think it takes a genius to know that Gov. Palin will not be a driving force in the future GOP.
reply: More bad news for the GOP. There have been 38 presidential elections since 1860, and Obama received the 6th highest share of the vote for a Democrat. Only FDR (four times) and LBJ (once) exceeded Obama’s percentage. There were three giant demographic shifts that powered this: “— The young broke more than 2-1 Democratic, and it was an intense preference unlikely to fade quickly. As this group ages and replaces older voters, Democrats will benefit even more since this group’s turnout will go up. “— The proportion of minority voters (black, Hispanic, and Asian) shot up and is likely to climb consistently every four years (mainly because of Hispanics). Democrats get about three-quarters of the votes of minorities, taken as a collective group. “— Americans with post-graduate educations have begun to move firmly to the Democrats, not just because of Bush and the economy but also because of the GOP’s conservative stance on social issues (abortion, gay rights, etc.) “Republicans will be in the wilderness for a while, whatever they do. If they want to shorten that time, though, they need to focus on the three populations we discuss in the book. There are many ways to increase their attractiveness, but one essential ingredient is to deemphasize social issues — as unhappy as that may make some fundamentalist Christians.” From a new book out by The University of Virginia’s Larry J. Sabato “The Year of Obama: How Barack Obama Won the White House.” http://www.politico.com/playbook/0409/playbook653.html
title: Gingrich: Palin won't be future GOP leader

content: quote: Originally posted by foxred03: Palin has done a pretty good job as Governor in Alaska. She had (and may still have) over an 80% approval rating before the election. She may have ended up as a decent candidate on the national stage in the future but she was not ready in 2008 and she will never recover from the beating she's taken (and continues to take). Most of it is her and John McCain's fault, but it is also true that there was a fair amount of simple bias. I agree. She wasn't ready, period. She wasn't McCain's pick, he wanted to pick Lieberman. Republicans want someone they can relate to, and they don't relate to her. She's a follower, and not a leader. She would have failed miserably if for some reason McCain couldn't finish out his term, which is ultimately what cost her.
quote: Originally posted by foxred03: Palin has done a pretty good job as Governor in Alaska. She had (and may still have) over an 80% approval rating before the election. She may have ended up as a decent candidate on the national stage in the future but she was not ready in 2008 and she will never recover from the beating she's taken (and continues to take). Most of it is her and John McCain's fault, but it is also true that there was a fair amount of simple bias.
reply: I agree. She wasn't ready, period. She wasn't McCain's pick, he wanted to pick Lieberman. Republicans want someone they can relate to, and they don't relate to her. She's a follower, and not a leader. She would have failed miserably if for some reason McCain couldn't finish out his term, which is ultimately what cost her.

Whether they want to admit it or not, it's true. Also, it doesn't help that Mexicans have finally seen through the cloud that Republicans have long held over their heads (as indicated by all the Blue votes along the Rio Grande on the last election). Actually I don't think the country has shifted to being more liberal I think that the Republican party has shifted further to the right with many of the local party organizations being controlled by religious and/or social conservatives. This control by the party extreme is the same problem that the Demos had from the 70's until the 90's (for the Demos the extreme left lost "control" after losing several elections) and will force Repub candidates to present positions most of the country will think are to extreme to get nominated.
